clinical_study.brief_title: Family Functioning and Child Behavior When a Sibling is Critically Ill
clinical_study.official_title: Family Functioning and Child Behavior When a Sibling is Critically Ill

brief_summary.textblock: The goal of this study is to determine if there is a correlation between an efficacious family environment and sibling behavior in families with children who are critically ill.

detailed_description.textblock: Families of critically ill children can face many emotional challenges during the course of a child's illness. While some research has looked at the impact on parents, there has been little focused on siblings. We want to better understand how social support may have a protective effect on siblings' quality of life. The goal of this study is to determine if there is a correlation between an efficacious family environment and sibling behavior in families with children who are critically ill. Our hypothesis is that a cohesive, emotionally rich and open family environment provides social support so that siblings can explore and express the difficult emotions that accompany illness, and is therefore a protective factor for a sibling's behavior.

primary_outcome.measure: To compare behavioral assessment scores of siblings of children who are critically ill to scores of the general population

secondary_outcome.measure: To assess if parents who receive results of sibling behavior scores and a brief intervention, compared to parents who do not receive this information or intervention, have a different perception of the sibling's strengths and difficulties.

intervention.intervention_name: One week follow up assessment results
intervention.description: FU-1 feedback group will receive child behavior assessment results and interpretation,and a brief intervention to encourage support options.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- adult (age 18 and older) who has decision making authority for CHOP patient who has been referred to the Pediatric Advanced Care Team (PACT) for palliative care services, and with a child(ren) age 6-11 years who is a sibling of the patient
- any race/ethnicity
Exclusion Criteria:
- Non-English speaking
